answer: <p>This is called an initialization list.  It is a way of initializing class members.  There are benefits to using this instead of simply assigning new values to the members in the body of the constructor, but if you have class members which are <em>constants</em> or <em>references</em> they <em>must</em> be initialized.</p>

<p>This is not obscure, it's the <a href="http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/initializer_list" rel="nofollow noreferrer">C++ initialization list syntax</a></p>

<p>Basically, in your case, <code>x</code> will be initialized with <code>_x</code>, <code>y</code> with <code>_y</code>, <code>z</code> with <code>_z</code>.</p>

<p>I don't know how you could miss this one, it's pretty basic. That's the syntax for initializing member variables or base class constructors.  It works for plain old data types as well as class objects.</p>

<p>You are correct, this is indeed a way to initialize member variables.  I'm not sure that there's much benefit to this, other than clearly expressing that it's an initialization.  Having a "bar=num" inside the code could get moved around, deleted, or misinterpreted much more easily.</p>

<p>there is another 'benefit'</p>

<p>if the member variable type does not support null initialization or if its a reference (which cannot be null initialized) then you have no choice but to supply an initialization list</p>

<p>It's an initialization list for the constructor. Instead of default constructing <code>x</code>, <code>y</code> and <code>z</code> and then assigning them the values received in the parameters, those members will be initialized with those values right off the bat. This may not seem terribly useful for <code>float</code>s, but it can be quite a timesaver with custom classes that are expensive to construct.</p>
